Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: New Measurements to Understand Coastal Ozone Production During the 2017 Lake Michigan Ozone Study
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project includes a multi-institutional team of scientists who are making advanced in-situ atmospheric measurements to investigate questions relevant to ozone formation and the occurrence of high concentrations of atmospheric ozone that can be damaging to human health. The Lake Michigan Ozone Study includes remote sensing activities being supported by NASA and the US EPA. The project will provide training for graduate and undergraduate researchers in atmospheric chemistry and build regional capacity in atmospheric science through a collaboration between university, state, and federal stakeholders.

The specific objectives of the proposal are to: (1) establish concentrations and speciation of key ozone-related chemicals (volatile organic compounds (VOC), nitrogen oxides (NOy), and VOC oxidation products) at a representative coastal site where high ozone levels commonly occur; (2) quantify and explain the role of the above species in dictating the production efficiency and NOx sensitivity driving coastal ozone; (3) determine the particulate and ozone influences of biogenic-rich and biogenic-poor regional air masses, urban plumes, localized emissions, and shipping for regional atmospheric chemistry; and (4) diagnose shortcomings and advance model skill for simulating critical aspects of coastal meteorology and chemistry in the current and future atmosphere. The results will improve the ability to predict high ozone episodes that may be harmful to human health and the environment.

The scientists supported by this award will deploy a Proton Transfer Reaction Quadrupole Interface Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometer, an Iodine Chemical Ionization Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometer, and off-line measurements of aerosol chemical and physical properties during the summer of 2017 at the Zion site in Lake County, Illinois located approximately 1000 m from the Lake Michigan coastline in the Illinois Beach State Park. The data collected will provide the additional information needed to address the important questions related to coastal ozone chemistry and its representation in current chemical transport models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ozone air pollution is an important issue because it causes respiratory health problems and reduces agricultural yields. Coastal environments with substantial ozone precursor emissions present an air quality management challenge, in part because of complex wind patterns.

Our NSF project, "New measurements to understand coastal ozone production during the 2017 Lake Michigan Ozone Study," was part of the Lake Michigan Ozone Study 2017 (LMOS 2017), a multiscale, multiplatform field campaign designed to evaluate the causes of elevated summertime ozone around Lake Michigan. During May and June 2017, a team of air pollution specialists, aerosol scientists, and atmospheric scientists measured gases and particles that make up air pollution, from ground-based monitors, mobile monitors, ships, and aircraft. This project outcomes report focuses primarily on the portion of LMOS 2017 funded by National Science Foundation Award 1712909.

Our measurements in Zion, Illinois were positioned to capture midday lake breeze conditions with high levels of air pollution. Our measurements included ozone and oxides of nitrogen (NOx) that are important regional air pollutants. They also include many particles and chemicals that help better explain the sources and causes of the specific levels of ozone air pollution seen over and around Lake Michigan. NSF funded research groups from the University of Iowa (Stanier and Stone), University of Wisconsin (Bertram), and University of Minnesota (Millet) led the Zion field site. Our research focuses on scientific questions regarding air pollution formation and movements in the region. The measurements are publicly available here: https://www-air.larc.nasa.gov/missions/lmos/

Three high ozone events were observed during the intensive measurement period: June 2, June 10-13, and June 15-17.  Winds and chemical measurements during these periods are being analyzed to answer our science questions. For example, there is strong interest in understanding whether ozone is more sensitive to NOx, or to volatile organic compounds (VOC). Having a confident answer to this sensitivity question enables better forecasts to warn people of bad air quality days, and allows development of more cost effective and science-based air quality management programs to improve air quality. We tested NOx versus VOC sensitivity for the most polluted plume arriving at Zion on June 2, 2017. By examining meteorology and the evolution of chemicals linked to ozone chemistry, we have determined that the air likely originated in the morning of June 2 from the Chicago area, and the air parcel was initially strongly sensitive to VOC, and gradually became more sensitive to NOx by the time it reached the coastal receptor at Zion, IL. This sensitivity has been replicated in two separate and independent computer simulations for June 2.

Another science question addressed by the LMOS 2017 team has been the sensitivity of ozone to emissions of natural chemicals from plants and forests. Sensitivity of ozone to these chemicals varies according to the simulation system used. A doubling of biogenic emissions increases average ozone in the southern portion of Lake Michigan by about 1.5 ppb in the WRF-Chem modeling system.

Analysis of particulate matter captured at Zion on June 2 revealed high levels of chemical tracers associated with anthropogenic combustion, including elemental carbon, lead, antimony, and ammonium sulfate. These findings point towards emissions from vehicles, power plants, and industry as important sources of ozone on this day. During June 10-13, the particulate matter contained relatively high concentrations of molecules that form from biogenic gases (like isoprene that is released from vegetation) when combined with anthropogenic pollution. Together these results demonstrate that anthropogenic pollution on its own, or in combination with biogenic emissions can lead to high particulate matter on days with elevated ozone concentrations.

LMOS 2017 has improved the science of oxidant modeling and thus improved both short and long term air quality planning. Through this project, graduate and undergraduate researchers gained training on a locally relevant but nationally important problem. The project team built novel regional capacity in atmospheric science by fostering collaboration between a diverse set of University, state, and federal stakeholders. The project team has organized or co-organized several meetings to coordinate and share in scientific discoveries, including monthly teleconferences, Science Synthesis Meeting in Chicago in September 2017, and a session on coastal air quality at the American Geophysical Union Meeting in 2018.  The team issued a preliminary synthesis report for all stakeholders "2017 Lake Michigan Ozone Study (LMOS) Preliminary Finding Report" in April 2019 and conducted a webinar for stakeholders in May 2019. A final synthesis report will be released as well. The scientists and graduate students of the project have given over 15 presentations and posters at national meetings, have published one peer-reviewed paper on LMOS 2017 to date, and have many additional publications in preparation. Researchers have communicated their scientific process and key findings more broadly to the community through the LMOS 2017 Open House in Sheboygan, radio interviews, newspaper articles, and a science cafe.
